1080. Painstaking effort should be made to induce suitable men to qualify themselves for this work. They should be men whose characters are based 
                                                                           255
upon the broad principles of the word of God, men who possess a natural energy, force, and perseverance that will enable them to reach a high standard of excellence. It is not every one who can make a successful physician. Many have entered upon the duties of this profession every way unprepared. They have not the requisite knowledge; neither have they the skill and tact, the carefulness and intelligence, necessary to insure success.--T., No. 32, p. 202.
